title: The Ark Captured
shortSummary: In 1 Samuel 5, the Philistines capture the Ark of the Covenant and place it in the temple of their god Dagon. However, God demonstrates His power by causing Dagon’s statue to fall and afflicting the Philistines with severe plagues, showing that the true God cannot be mocked or contained by pagan idols. This chapter highlights God's sovereignty and holiness, warning against disrespecting His presence.
timeline: c. 1100 BC - Period of the Judges and early monarchy in Israel

keyCharacters.name: Philistines
keyCharacters.description: A powerful neighboring people who capture the Ark of the Covenant and suffer God's judgment as a result.

keyCharacters.name: Dagon
keyCharacters.description: The chief god of the Philistines, whose idol is humbled by God when the Ark is placed beside it.

keyCharacters.name: Priests of Dagon
keyCharacters.description: Religious leaders who serve Dagon and are affected by the desecration of their god’s image.

definitions.definition: The sacred chest containing the tablets of the Ten Commandments, symbolizing God's presence among Israel.
An archaic term for hemorrhoids or painful swellings, used here to describe the afflictions God sent on the Philistines.
The entrance or doorway of a building; in this chapter, the place where Dagon’s statue was found fallen and broken.

outline.heading: The Ark Taken to Ashdod and the Fall of Dagon
outline.description: The Philistines bring the Ark into the temple of Dagon in Ashdod, but the idol falls face down before the Ark, losing its head and hands. This demonstrates the superiority of the God of Israel over pagan gods.

outline.heading: God’s Judgment on Ashdod
outline.description: God’s hand brings a severe plague of emerods upon the people of Ashdod, causing death and suffering, leading the Philistines to recognize the Ark cannot remain with them.

outline.heading: The Ark Moved to Gath and Ekron with Continued Judgment
outline.description: The Philistines move the Ark to other cities, Gath and Ekron, but God’s judgment follows, causing widespread affliction and fear, prompting the Philistines to seek to return the Ark to Israel.

application: Respect and honor the holiness of God’s presence; do not treat sacred things with irreverence or presumption.
Recognize God’s sovereignty over all nations and idols, trusting that He is supreme over any earthly power.
Respond to God’s discipline with humility and repentance rather than stubbornness or defiance.
Seek God’s protection and presence rightly, understanding that He is not to be manipulated or used for personal gain.

keyVerses.text: And when they of Ashdod arose early on the morrow, behold, Dagon was fallen upon his face to the earth before the ark of the LORD.
keyVerses.significance: This verse powerfully illustrates the defeat of the Philistine god Dagon before the true God, emphasizing God's supremacy.

keyVerses.text: But the hand of the LORD was heavy upon them of Ashdod, and he destroyed them, and smote them with emerods, even Ashdod and the coasts thereof.
keyVerses.significance: It shows God’s direct judgment on those who oppose Him, warning against disrespecting His holiness.

keyVerses.text: And when the men of Ashdod saw that it was so, they said, The ark of the God of Israel shall not abide with us: for his hand is sore upon us, and upon Dagon our god.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals the fear and acknowledgment of God’s power by the Philistines, a testimony to His unmatched authority.
